title-group.article-title: Neighborhood Disadvantage and Verbal Ability as Explanations of the Black–White Difference in Adolescent Violence
title-group.subtitle: Toward an Integrated Model

author-notes.corresp: Thomas L. McNulty, Sociology Department, The University of Georgia, 312 Baldwin Hall, Athens, GA 30602-1611, USA Email: tmcnulty@uga.edu

abstract.p: This article develops a multilevel model that integrates individual difference and sociological explanations of the Black–White difference in adolescent violence. Our basic premise is that low verbal ability is a criminogenic risk factor that is in part an outcome of exposure to neighborhood and family disadvantages. Analysis of the 1997 National Longitudinal Survey of Youth reveals that verbal ability has direct and indirect effects (through school achievement) on violence, provides a partial explanation for the racial disparity, and mediates the effect of socioeconomic disadvantage at the neighborhood level. Results support the view that neighborhood and family disadvantages have repercussions for the acquisition of verbal ability, which, in turn, serves as a protective factor against violence. We conclude that explanation of the race difference is best conceived as originating from the segregation of Blacks in disadvantaged contexts.

body.p: Data document higher rates of violence among Black compared with White adolescents (Hawkins, Laub, Lauritsen, & Cothern, 2000). Research in the social disorganization tradition (Shaw & McKay, 1942) argues that the disproportionate involvement in violence among Blacks is confounded with neighborhood disadvantage and a product of persistent segregation and residential inequality (Krivo, Peterson, & Kuhl, 2009; Sampson & Wilson, 1995; Wilson, 2009). Violence among Blacks has also been attributed to racial differences in family contexts (Lareau, 2003) and to delinquent subcultures (e.g., gang, drug) and street codes that support the use of violence as a means of conflict resolution in impoverished neighborhoods (Anderson, 1999; Heimer, 1997; Stewart, Schreck, & Simons, 2006; Stewart & Simons, 2006). Findings from recent studies are consistent with these arguments, indicating that the racial difference in violence is nonsignificant (or reduced) once neighborhood and family disadvantages are held constant (Bellair & McNulty, 2005; Lauritsen & White, 2001; McNulty & Bellair, 2003a, 2003b; Sampson, Morenoff, & Raudenbush, 2005).

A prominent alternative to the sociological approach highlights constitutional differences between individuals in measured intelligence (IQ) and other traits (for a review, see Ellis & Walsh, 2003). This is most telling in works such as The Bell Curve, in which Herrnstein and Murray (1994) conclude that racial differences in criminal outcomes are largely a function of “genetic endowment,” and that social policy would do better by focusing on cognitive disadvantage rather than on problems of poverty and unemployment. Subsequent debate led to vehement critiques that Herrnstein and Murray, by failing to adequately control for socioeconomic status (SES) and other factors, overstated the role of IQ in accounting for racial differences in crime (Cullen, Gendreau, Jarjoura, & Wright, 1997; Fischer et al., 1996).

Nevertheless, several meta-analyses reveal that low IQ is a criminogenic risk factor and therefore an individual difference that should be incorporated into theories of crime (Ellis & Walsh, 2003; Hirschi & Hindelang, 1977). Given the documented test score gap between Blacks and Whites, and evidence that gaps in cognitive skills appear early in life (Farkas & Beron, 2004; Jencks & Phillips, 1998), it is a logical deduction to surmise that variation in cognitive abilities may play a role in accounting for the race difference in violence. Although low IQ may be a robust predictor of violence, its potential to explain racial disparities has only recently been examined (Bellair & McNulty, 2005; Sampson et al., 2005). In particular, few studies of the racial disparity in adolescent violence integrate individual-level differences with a national sample design that captures a wide variety of neighborhood contexts.

Drawing on prior research, our modeling highlights verbal ability as a critical building block of cognitive development (Farkas & Beron, 2004; Moffitt, Lynam, & Silva, 1994) and distinguishes its effect on violence from that of academic achievement. Some ability tests may reflect school achievement as well as innate aptitude because they are written tests and require knowledge of academic subjects. Thus, observed gaps in verbal ability by race and social class may be confounded with differences in educational opportunity that are rooted in neighborhood stratification. Recent findings show that verbal ability test scores are lowered among Black children residing in disadvantaged neighborhoods (Sampson, Sharkey, & Raudenbush, 2008).

In this article, we combine an individual difference model that emphasizes variation in verbal ability with a structural model that views poor verbal skills as one manifestation of the social isolation characteristic of extremely poor neighborhoods. Low verbal ability has ramifications for success in and attachment to school and the labor force, and in turn for susceptibility to violent behavior. Specifically, verbal ability is expected to explain a portion of the “race” effect and is hypothesized to have direct and indirect effects (through school achievement) on violence that mediate the effect of structural disadvantage at the neighborhood level. Although social variables that are outcomes of or correlated with residence in disadvantaged neighborhoods (e.g., delinquent peers and victimization experiences) are also expected to explain the race disparity, verbal ability is clearly implicated in the explanation. To test the hypotheses, we estimate three-level hierarchical models using data from the first five waves of the 1997 National Longitudinal Survey of Youth (NLSY 97) matched with block-group data from the 2000 Census.

The first five waves of the NLSY 97 comprise a nationally representative sample of adolescents between the ages of 12 and 20, a critical period of adolescent development that captures the onset, peak, and decline in violence involvement over time. The data also include a wide variety of residential neighborhoods. Our results contradict recent research that uses contextual methods and different data sets to assess the relative contribution of neighborhood contexts and verbal ability to explanation of the race difference in violence (Bellair & McNulty, 2005; Sampson et al., 2005). Findings in this article indicate a larger role for verbal ability, both as a robust predictor of adolescent violence and as a partial explanation for the Black–White difference. We extend prior work by further developing theory that places individual differences in neighborhood context, which provides an explanation for the racial gap in violence that is most consistent with the available evidence.

sec.title: Toward an Integrated Model of the Race Difference in Violence
sec.p: Psychologists are increasingly convinced that “poor verbal ability is the active ingredient for delinquency in the omnibus IQ” (Moffitt et al., 1994, p. 293). We conceive of verbal ability as an essential element of human development that may alter an individual’s trajectory or timely transition during the life course. Poor verbal ability affects the capacity to interpret and respond appropriately to the surrounding social environment and may elicit negative reactions from teachers and peers. Indeed, the ability to understand and communicate language facilitates attachment to and adequate performance in school—a major societal institution and a powerful protective factor in delinquency prevention.

The argument that verbal ability is influenced by the neighborhood and family contexts in which children live is based on several streams of evidence. Research suggests that neighborhood disadvantage weakens the family learning environment and fosters inconsistency in parental practices, which in turn may bear on cognitive achievement (Furstenburg, Cook, Eccles, Elder, & Sameroff, 1999). Poor families lack the social and economic resources required for the nurturing of effective learning within the home (e.g., help with homework, computer access), and evidence suggests different styles of parenting by social class (Lareau, 2011).

Verbal ability may also be confounded with the availability and quality of resources in schools. The quality of the school environment is often linked with the quality of the neighborhood context in which the school is located, and school climates that are not conducive to learning may undermine acquisition of verbal skills by discouraging a commitment to learning (Kozol, 1991). In addition, disadvantaged neighborhoods may restrict the kinds of public verbal interactions that enhance verbal skills and limit access to “communication infrastructures” that serve as models of learning (Kim & Ball-Rokeach, 2006). Neighborhood disadvantage is associated with reduced institutional resources, including the availability of learning, recreational, and social activities. Particularly consequential are learning activities such as “libraries, family resource centers, literacy programs, and museums,” the absence of which “may influence children’s development, especially school readiness and achievement outcomes” (Leventhal & Brooks-Gunn, 2000, p. 322). Perhaps most important, racial segregation and social isolation may limit the exposure of parents and children to standard academic English, a critical factor for success in school and the labor market (Massey & Denton, 1993; Sampson et al., 2008; Wilson, 2009).

The influence of neighborhood disadvantage on test scores is illustrated by Sampson et al.’s (2008) longitudinal analysis of trajectories in verbal ability among Black children (ages 6-12) growing up in Chicago neighborhoods in 1995. They find that living in an extremely disadvantaged neighborhood significantly reduces the later verbal ability of Black children by a magnitude that rivals missing a year or more of schooling. Moreover, the strongest effects appear several years after children live in areas of concentrated disadvantage, indicating that neighborhood effects on growth in verbal ability may be cumulative and persist overtime even if a child moves out of a disadvantaged neighborhood. Exposure to concentrated disadvantage thus appears to have detrimental and long-lasting consequences for the development of cognitive skills that are crucial for subsequent achievement.

Sampson et al. (2005), using census and survey data for Chicago neighborhoods, compare the relative contribution of neighborhood contexts and verbal ability with explanation of differences in violence among Whites, Blacks, and Latinos. Their multilevel models show that a majority of the Black–White difference and the entire Latino–White gap in violence are accounted for by indicators of parental marital status, immigrant generation, and neighborhood social contexts. Among the factors included in their full model, indicators of neighborhood context are the most important source of the reduction in the Black–White gap in violence, whereas constitutional differences are least important. Consistent with a long line of research, measured verbal ability is a significant predictor of violence but does not appear in their data to have much efficacy as an explanation of race and violence.

We are aware of only one recent study that directly assesses the role of neighborhood contexts and verbal ability in the etiology of violence among adolescents using national data. Bellair and McNulty (2005) use a sample of adolescents from the National Longitudinal Survey of Adolescent Health matched with block-group data from the 1990 Census, and an age-standardized score from the Peabody Picture Vocabulary Test–Revised (PPVT-R) to indicate verbal ability. Verbal ability is revealed to have only small, indirect effects on violence through school achievement and contributes little to explanation of the racial disparity. The analysis also reveals that verbal ability scores are significantly lower among adolescents who live in areas of concentrated disadvantage and in low-SES families.

The analysis presented below is intended to add to this growing body of research that places individual risk and protective factors for delinquency and violence in neighborhood context. Figure 1 presents the integrated model of the race difference in violence. We do not test all of the causal linkages in the figure, but it is a useful heuristic that summarizes the main themes of the arguments discussed above. It begins with the assertion that economic vulnerability combined with historic and contemporary discrimination in housing markets concentrates Blacks in neighborhoods with heightened disadvantage. Neighborhood disadvantage has detrimental repercussions for adolescents, including diminished family SES, exposure to delinquent peers, increased risk of victimization, underdeveloped verbal ability, and negative school experiences, which in turn heighten the risk for violence. Rather than conceptualize verbal ability solely in terms of heredity, the integrated model argues that verbal skills are in part outcomes of neighborhood and family contexts and partially mediate the latter’s effects on violence. Verbal ability and school achievement are more proximate causes in the model, and achievement is hypothesized to mediate much of the effect of verbal ability on violence.

sec.title: Sample
sec.p: We test the model with data from the first five waves of the NLSY 97. The NLSY 97 is a household-based, nationally representative sample of adolescents between the ages of 12 and 16 at the time of first interview and who have been interviewed yearly since 1997, including an oversample of Blacks. Screening interviews in each sampled household resulted in 9,806 eligible subjects, 8,984 of whom participated yielding a 91.6% response rate. By the fifth round, 7,884 respondents from the initial sample completed interviews, yielding an overall 87.7% retention rate (that does not vary by racial group). The analysis is restricted to non-Hispanic Blacks and Whites and to neighborhoods in which there are at least two respondents (to ensure a more reliable estimate of the between-neighborhood variance component), resulting in a sample of 5,322 adolescents (3,521 White and 1,801 Black) nested within 1,237 neighborhoods with 26,610 time-varying observations pooled over five waves of data (i.e., 5 × 5,322).1 Table 1 presents the descriptive statistics for variables.

sec.title: Level 1 Measures (Within Individual)
sec.p: The dependent variable is indicated by the number of violent acts committed in each wave and is measured with an item that asks respondents whether they have attacked someone with the intention of hurting them in the past year (or since the date of last interview) and, if yes, to indicate the frequency with which they did so. Our violence outcome counts the number of violent attacks engaged in within each wave and ranges from 0 to 99 events. Given extensive skew, we treat the outcome as a Poisson sampling distribution with constant exposure and overdispersion.2

Time is reflected in each wave by age, which is measured in months. Given the age range of the sample over the study period (12-20 years), we anticipate a curvilinear relationship where the frequency of violence increases between 12 and 16 or 17 years of age after which involvement declines (see Bilchik, 1998). To capture the age-violence curve, we include a quadratic term for age. The average age of respondents over the study period is about 17 years (207 months).

We additionally control for time-varying predictors of violence at Level 1 as a means to assess their role in accounting for the race difference. A dummy variable is included to adjust for residence in urban locales, where involvement in violence is expected to be greater relative to rural and suburban places (Krivo & Peterson, 1996). Black adolescents are far more likely to reside in urban neighborhoods (48%) compared with their White counterparts (18%). Family structure is coded with a binary variable in each wave that distinguishes respondents who reside in single-parent families from subjects who live in other family types, given research showing that the risk for negative social outcomes is higher among children growing up in single-parent families (McLanahan & Sandefur, 1994). Black adolescents are substantially and significantly more likely to reside in single-parent households (44%) compared with White adolescents (20%). Finally, given research showing that drug use is a significant predictor of adolescent violence (Farrington & Loeber, 1999), we control for each subject’s reported use of drugs (including marijuana, cocaine, and heroin) with a binary variable in each wave (use drugs = 1). A fair percentage of the NLSY 97 subjects (16%) report using drugs over the study period, with White adolescents evidencing a higher mean compared with their Black counterparts.3

sec.title: Level 2 Measures (Between Person)
sec.p: Self-reported racial background is represented by a binary variable that distinguishes non-Hispanic Blacks and Whites (referent). Thirty-four percent of the sample is Black (n = 1,801), including the oversample available with the NLSY 97. We apply the sample weight to correct for disproportionate probability of selection. Gender is included given well-documented higher rates of violence among males (female is the referent). We include family income, available in the first wave, as an indicator of family economic well-being given evidence of an inverse relationship with violence (Bilchik, 1998) and significant differences between Blacks and Whites (see Table 1). Family income is measured in dollars and averages US$49,424 for the full sample, US$59,653 for Whites, and US$29,428 for Blacks (z scored in the analysis).

Two indicators, available in the first wave, are included to control the influence of exposure to delinquent peers and antisocial subcultures (Akers, 1998; Warr, 2002). Exposure to delinquent peers is measured by combining two items into a z score that reflect the percentage of each subject’s peers in their grade at school (or when they were in school) that are gang members and the percentage that use drugs. The response set for each item ranges from one to five, with one indicating that almost none belong to a gang or use drugs and five indicating that almost all (more than 90%) belong to a gang or use drugs. Compared with White adolescents, Blacks evidence a significantly higher mean on the indicator of delinquent peers. An additional indicator of exposure to antisocial contexts reflects whether respondents have been a victim of violence in the past 5 years (available in the fifth wave), which has been linked to an increased likelihood of violent perpetration (Lauritsen, Sampson, & Laub, 1991; Macmillan, 2001; Shaffer & Ruback, 2002). Roughly 6% of the sample report being the victim of violence over the study period.

Verbal ability is measured using the Armed Services Vocational Aptitude Battery (ASVAB), which was administered to NLSY 97 respondents during the first wave for the purpose of establishing national norms. The ASVAB comprises 12 separate tests that measure knowledge and skill in wide-ranging competencies. We measure verbal ability using a principal components regression factor that combines final ability estimates from the word knowledge and paragraph comprehension subsections (see also Koenig, Frey, & Detterman, 2008; Roberts, Anjoul, Kyllonen, Pallier, & Stankov, 2000).4 Consistent with prior research (e.g., Jencks & Phillips, 1998), Black adolescents score significantly below Whites on the verbal ability test.

As noted above, we expect the effect of verbal ability on violence to be partially mediated by school achievement. School achievement is indicated by the highest grade completed in school, which averages about 11 years for the sample. Whereas verbal ability reflects the range of verbal skills that have been acquired inside and outside of school, educational attainment reflects involvement and investment in school independent of ability, and also indicates the extent to which an adolescent’s time is structured within a prosocial institution.

We also suspect that verbal ability effects may be partly confounded with school environments that are more or less favorable to learning, and hence we control for the general climate in the school that respondents attend (or in the last school that they attended). School climate is measured in the first wave and is indicated by a regression factor score that comprises items (e.g., threatened to be hurt, had something stolen, and feels safe at school) that reflect how conducive the school environment is to learning and prosocial behavior. A higher value on the scale indicates a more disruptive school climate, and is thus expected to be positively related to violence. Table 1 reveals that Black adolescents report attending schools with more disruptive climates than their White counterparts.

sec.title: Level 3 Measures (Between Neighborhood)
sec.p: Neighborhood disadvantage is measured with block-group data obtained during the 2000 U.S. Census and is attached to each respondent’s record based on the latitude and longitude of the home address in any given wave. Neighborhood disadvantage is a principal components regression factor comprising the percentage of the population living below the poverty threshold, the percentage unemployed, and the percentage of households headed by a female. The component variables have high factor loadings and strong internal reliability (α = .82). There is substantial variation in the neighborhood disadvantage to which youth are exposed, with rates of poverty, unemployment, and female-headed households ranging from 0% to 73% across neighborhoods. Table 1 reveals that Black adolescents reside in neighborhoods with significantly higher levels of structural disadvantage.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Table 2 presents Poisson regressions of violent attacks on race, verbal ability, and control variables. Model 1 displays an unconditional growth model including only age as a predictor at Level 1. The unconditional growth model reveals that 61% of the variance in violence involvement is between persons (variance component = 2.496), whereas 8% is between neighborhoods (variance component = 0.309) and 31% represents within-person temporal variation at Level 1 (variance component = 1.268). Consistent with the literature, the age effect is nonlinear reflecting an age-violence curve of increasing involvement in violence during early adolescence (12-15 years), a peak during midadolescence (16 years), followed by declining involvement in late adolescence (17-20 years). We do not find evidence of variation in the age-violence trajectory by race. The variance components for the Level 2 (2.496) and Level 3 (0.309) intercepts are statistically significant (p < .001), indicating between-person and between-neighborhood variability in violence event rates. Using the formulas provided by Snijders and Bosker (1999) and Raudenbush and Bryk (2002), we use Model 1 as a baseline from which to calculate variance explained statistics for predictors added to the unconditional growth model.

sec.p: Model 2 controls for race and gender at Level 2 and age and the additional control variables at Level 1, which establishes the greater involvement of Black adolescents in violence compared with Whites (.509; p < .001). The control variables are also significant in expected directions. Violence event rates are significantly higher among males, among those who reside in urban areas and in single-parent families, and especially among those who are involved with drugs. The variance components for the Level 2 (2.333) and Level 3 (.300) intercepts have been reduced somewhat but remain statistically significant (p < .001), indicating that unexplained variance in violence event rates between persons and between neighborhoods remains. Model 2 explains about 5% and 6% of the variance at Level 1 and Level 2, respectively.

Model 3 incorporates the neighborhood disadvantage index at Level 3, which has a strong, positive effect on violence event rates (.242; p < .001). Controlling for neighborhood disadvantage reduces the Black coefficient substantially by 51% (.509 to .249), although the effect remains significant at the .05 level. This result is consistent with literature that suggests that the disproportionate involvement in violence among Black adolescents is partly confounded with neighborhood disadvantage. Model 4 adds verbal ability to the equation, which has the hypothesized negative effect on violence (−.380; p < .001). Most important, incorporating verbal ability fully explains the Black effect, reducing the coefficient by an additional 90% (.249 to .026). Thus, contradicting prior research (Bellair & McNulty, 2005; Sampson et al., 2005), individual differences in verbal ability are shown to contribute substantially to explanation of the Black–White disparity in violence. We also argued above that the effect of neighborhood disadvantage on violence may partly operate through verbal ability. Findings in Model 4 provide some support, showing that the effect of neighborhood disadvantage, although remaining significant, is reduced by 32% when verbal ability is added to the equation (.242 to .165).

Model 5 in Table 2 adds the indicators of school achievement (highest grade) and school climate, which have the expected effects on violence. Consistent with the theoretical model and past research, much of the effect of verbal ability on violence appears to be indirect, operating primarily through school achievement. Controlling for highest grade (and school climate) reduces the verbal ability coefficient by 66% (−.380 to −.130), suggestive of mediation. In addition, Model 5 supports our argument that the effect of neighborhood disadvantage on violence is substantially mediated by verbal ability and subsequent school attainment. Adding highest grade and school climate to the equation reduces the disadvantage coefficient by an additional 55% to nonsignificance (.165 to .075). Model 5 explains about 10% of the variance in violence at Level 1 and about 12% of the variance at Level 2. The Level 3 variance component is reduced by about 25%, relative to the unconditional growth model (.309 − .231 / .309). Importantly, the final model in Table 2 (Model 6) reveals that including neighborhood disadvantage in the equations is required to account for the Black effect.

Table 3 presents an alternative model specification that highlights the influence on violence of family income, delinquent peers, and victimization experiences, and their contribution to explanation of the race difference. Model 1 shows that these predictors have theoretically consistent effects on violence and together also fully explain the race disparity in violence, reducing the Black coefficient (.249 to .107) by 57% (compare with Model 3 in Table 2). There is also evidence that the social variables partly mediate the neighborhood disadvantage effect as well; incorporating these predictors reduces the disadvantage coefficient by 52% (.242, p < .001 to .117, p < .05). As shown in the second model in Table 3, and consistent with results in Table 2, controlling for neighborhood disadvantage is necessary to explain the Black effect.

sec.p: The final model shows the fully specified equation, in which both the disadvantage and Black effects on violence are entirely mediated (i.e., reduced to zero). The full model explains 11% and 14% of the variance at Level 1 and Level 2, respectively, and reduces the Level 3 variance component by about 30%. Also noteworthy, and consistent with the theoretical model, is that the effect of family income is reduced to borderline significance (−.088, p < .10), primarily as a function of verbal ability. These results support the view that neighborhood and family disadvantages have detrimental repercussions for the acquisition of verbal ability which, in turn, serves as a significant protective factor against violence.

sec.title: Discussion and Conclusion
sec.p: This article integrates an individual difference approach that emphasizes variation in verbal ability with a sociological approach that highlights neighborhood disadvantage, both of which are relevant to explanation of the race difference in violence. Black children are far more likely than their White counterparts to grow up in neighborhoods featuring high rates of structural disadvantage, which has repercussions for the acquisition of verbal skills that are crucial for achievement in school and the labor market. Our results show that low verbal ability and diminished school attainment are criminogenic risk factors that are in part outcomes of exposure to neighborhood disadvantage. Verbal ability partly mediates the effect of disadvantage at the neighborhood level and in turn provides a succinct explanation for the racial disparity in violence.

Although sociological variables also explain the race disparity, verbal ability in conjunction with neighborhood disadvantage reduces the Black–White gap in violence to zero and is thus part of the explanation. This contradicts recent research that has found that verbal ability scores, while related to violence, contribute little to the explanation of race and violence (Bellair & McNulty, 2005; Sampson et al., 2005). Yet that the effect of disadvantage on violence is mediated by verbal ability and school achievement indicates that exposure to neighborhood disadvantage is a critical part of the process underlying the disproportionate involvement in violence among Black adolescents.

Indeed, controlling for neighborhood disadvantage in the models is required to account for the race difference, whether individual differences in verbal ability or sociological variables indicating family well-being, exposure to delinquent peers, and victimization experiences are considered. Neighborhood disadvantage heightens the risk for violence in part by diminishing verbal skills and subsequent achievement in and attachment to school, which places adolescents at a disadvantage in the competition for grades, admission to college, and rewarding employment—which are known to establish a strong foundation for prosocial bonds. We conclude that explanation of the race difference is best conceived as originating from the segregation of Blacks in disadvantaged contexts.

Moffitt (1994) has argued that the race difference in crime is accounted for by a higher prevalence of adolescent-limited and life-course-persistent offenders among Blacks, largely due to institutionalized discrimination and poverty. Moffitt’s arguments regarding life-course-persistent offending among Blacks have received mixed support (Donnellan, Ge, & Wenk, 2000; Haynie, Weiss, & Piquero, 2008; Piquero & White, 2003). Donnellan et al. (2000) find that Moffitt’s theory is supported for Whites and Latinos, but is less applicable to Blacks. Specifically, whereas Whites and Latinos with high cognitive skills desist from crime as they reach adulthood, their Black counterparts do not. The authors surmise that the protective effects of cognitive skills are not as influential in the disadvantaged contexts in which Blacks disproportionately reside (see also Bellair & McNulty, 2010; Piquero, Moffitt, & Lawton, 2005). Future research should investigate the possibility that the influence of verbal ability (and other individual traits) on delinquency and violence may be conditioned by neighborhood contexts and race.

In sum, results suggest that interventions to improve conditions in poor neighborhoods may reduce the race difference in verbal ability and adolescent violence by helping to support stable families, reducing exposure to antisocial learning, and by enhancing attachment and commitment to school among children. Strengthening families and early childhood learning in distressed neighborhoods may help reduce the substantial risk for violence associated with frustration and in some cases failure in school. In particular, targeting early childhood development may help reduce the racial gap in verbal ability that appears early in life and contributes to differences in social outcomes, including success in school and susceptibility to violent behavior.

Regression imputation with random error components was used to replace missing values on explanatory measures (Jinn & Sedransk, 1989). To ensure that the reported results are not sensitive to imputation, we replicated our models using listwise deletion of cases with missing values, and there are no substantive differences.

For example, at Level 1 we model, ηijk = log(λijk), where λijk is the event rate reflecting the frequency of violence, and ηijk is the log of the event rate. Note that while λijk is constrained to be nonnegative, log(λijk) can take on any value. The predicted log event rate can be converted to an event rate by generating λijk = exponential{ηijk}.

The “use drugs” measure works to suppress the race difference in violence (i.e., makes the difference more pronounced when included in the models) and hence is important to control for. This suppression is a function of the “use drugs” measure being strongly and positively related to violence, as is the Black effect, yet Blacks are less likely to report using drugs compared with their Whites counterparts (see Table 1).

For a detailed description of the Armed Services Vocational Aptitude Battery (ASVAB) administration in 1997 National Longitudinal Survey of Youth (NLSY 97), see Appendix 10 of the NLSY 97 codebook supplement.

The reported findings are robust across a variety of alternative model specifications and operationalizations of the violence scale (sensitivity analyses are available upon request). We also examined the models for signs of multicollinearity with item intercorrelations, variance inflation factors (VIFs), and whether standard errors increase across equations. None of the VIFs came close to exceeding the critical value of 4.0 (Fisher & Mason, 1981) and the other tests also indicate that multicollinearity is not at play in the analysis.

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Thomas L. McNulty is an associate professor at the University of Georgia. His recent work focuses on testing multilevel theoretical models of racial/ethnic differences in crime and violence, with emphasis on the role of family, school, and community contexts. His related research examines the sociocultural and community risk factors for violence among adolescents and young adults.

Paul E. Bellair is a professor of sociology at The Ohio State University. His research interests include crime in community context, race/ethnic differences in violence, life course criminology, and hierarchical models. His current research examines the relationship between labor market conditions and parolee recidivism, measurement of and relationship between community organization and crime, and neighborhood effects on drug use and criminal behavior in the months preceding incarceration.

Stephen J. Watts is a PhD candidate in the Department of Sociology at the University of Georgia. His research focuses on the testing of criminological theories, community causes and correlates of offending, and the integration of criminological theory into a biosocial framework for explaining criminal and deviant behaviors.
